pageProps.contentHtml:
conformal mappings

Consider the following region in the complex plane:

Ω={x+iy | 0<x<∞ and 0<y<1x}.\Omega = \set{x + iy \st 0 < x < \infty \text{ and } 0 < y < \frac{1}{x}}.Ω={x+iy∣∣​0<x<∞ and 0<y<x1​}.

Exhibit an explicit conformal mapping fff of Ω\OmegaΩ onto D\DD.
Solution.

Let g(z)=z2g\p{z} = z^2g(z)=z2 so that g(x+iy)=x2−y2+2ixyg\p{x + iy} = x^2 - y^2 + 2ixyg(x+iy)=x2−y2+2ixy. Since Ω\OmegaΩ is a subset of the upper half-plane, it follows that ggg is a conformal map onto its image. We claim that g(Ω)={x+iy | 0<y<2}g\p{\Omega} = \set{x + iy \st 0 < y < 2}g(Ω)={x+iy∣0<y<2}. If x+iy∈Ωx + iy \in \Omegax+iy∈Ω, then by definition,

0<xy<1  ⟹  0<Im⁡g(x+iy)=2xy<2.0 < xy < 1 \implies 0 < \Im{g\p{x + iy}} = 2xy < 2.0<xy<1⟹0<Img(x+iy)=2xy<2.

Conversely, given x+iyx + iyx+iy with 0<y<20 < y < 20<y<2, we need to solve

a2−b2=xand2ab=ya^2 - b^2 = x \quad\text{and}\quad 2ab = ya2−b2=xand2ab=y

for a+ib∈Ωa + ib \in \Omegaa+ib∈Ω. Observe that

x=a2−b2=a2−y24a2  ⟹  4a4−4a2x−y2=0  ⟹  a2=4x±16x2+16y28.\begin{aligned} x = a^2 - b^2 = a^2 - \frac{y^2}{4a^2} &\implies 4a^4 - 4a^2x - y^2 = 0 \\ &\implies a^2 = \frac{4x \pm \sqrt{16x^2 + 16y^2}}{8}. \end{aligned}x=a2−b2=a2−4a2y2​​⟹4a4−4a2x−y2=0⟹a2=84x±16x2+16y2​​.​

Since a>0a > 0a>0, we have

a2=x+x2+y22>0,a^2 = \frac{x + \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}}{2} > 0,a2=2x+x2+y2​​>0,

so such an a+iba + iba+ib exists in Ω\OmegaΩ, and so ggg maps Ω\OmegaΩ to a strip. Thus, h(z)=eπz2/2h\p{z} = e^{\pi z^2/2}h(z)=eπz2/2 maps Ω\OmegaΩ to the upper half-plane, so

f(z)=h(z)−ih(z)+i=eπz2/2−ieπz2/2+if\p{z} = \frac{h\p{z} - i}{h\p{z} + i} = \frac{e^{\pi z^2/2} - i}{e^{\pi z^2/2} + i}f(z)=h(z)+ih(z)−i​=eπz2/2+ieπz2/2−i​

is the map we want.
